content: An annoyance of not committing to a specific payload is that you need to deal with slashings for payload equivocation, which is not nice at all.

author: potuz
content: Started specing such an option out and modulo equivocations is all much simpler, but dealing with these extra slashing conditions and proving still safety is not trivial.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
Sharing a new post too: https://mirror.xyz/barnabe.eth/LJUb_TpANS0VWi3TOwGx_fgomBvqPaQ39anVj3mnCOg

What's relevant for this channel (imo): Considering ePBS as the protocol concerning itself with the allocation of *building* rights, and ETs as the protocol no longer giving out *proposing* rights to the validators by default, but instead putting these rights up for sale. Proposing rights could be thought of as "who ultimately receives the value from the payload", whereas building rights are more about "who can decide what the payload should contain". Hopefully this distinction allows for more conceptual clarity of how everything fits together, there is surely more to say about it but I wanted to publish early
